description: From Middle English clene, clane, from Old English clǣne (“clean, pure”), from Proto-West Germanic *klaini, from Proto-Germanic *klainiz (“shining, fine, splendid, tender”), from Proto-Indo-European *glēy- (“gleaming”), from Proto-Indo-European *gel- (“to gleam”).

Cognate with Scots clean (“absolute, pure, clear, empty”) and clene, clane (“clean”), North Frisian klien (“small”), Dutch klein (“small”), Low German kleen (“small”), German klein (“small”), Swedish klen (“weak, feeble, delicate”), Icelandic klénn (“poor, feeble, petty, snug, puny, cheesy, lame”).

entries.meaning: Not dirty.
examples: Are these dishes clean?  Your room is finally clean!

entries.meaning: In an unmarked condition.
examples: Put a clean sheet of paper into the printer.

entries.meaning: (aerodynamics) Allowing an uninterrupted flow over surfaces, without protrusions such as racks or landing gear.
(aviation) Having the undercarriage and flaps in the up position.
examples: Antonym: dirty

entries.meaning: Empty.
examples: The cargo hold is clean.  Mister, I want to see a clean dinner plate or there'll be no dessert for you.

entries.meaning: (of metal) Having relatively few impurities.
examples: clean steel

entries.meaning: Pure, especially morally or religiously.
examples: Our kids can watch this movie because it is clean.

entries.meaning: Not having used drugs or alcohol.
examples: I've been clean this time for eight months.

entries.meaning: (of criminal, driving, etc. records) Without restrictions or penalties, or someone having such a record.
examples: Unlike you, I’ve never caused any accidents — my record is still clean!

entries.meaning: (informal) Not in possession of weapons or contraband such as drugs.
examples: I'm clean, officer. You can go ahead and search me if you want.

entries.meaning: (informal) Devoid of profanity.
Smooth, exact, and performed well.
examples: I'll need a sharper knife to make clean cuts.  a clean leap over a fence

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Total; utter. (still in "clean sweep")
(informal) Cool or neat.
examples: Wow, Dude, those are some clean shoes ya got there!

entries.meaning: (health) Being free of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs).
examples: I want to make sure my fiancé is clean before we are married.

entries.meaning: That does not damage the environment.
examples: clean energy;  clean coal

entries.meaning: Free from that which is useless or injurious; without defects.
examples: clean land;  clean timber

entries.meaning: Free from restraint or neglect; complete; entire.
Well-proportioned; shapely.
examples: clean limbs

entries.meaning: (climbing, of a route) Ascended without falling.
Fully and completely.
examples: He was stabbed clean through.
You must be clean mad.

entries.meaning: Removal of dirt.
examples: This place needs a clean.

entries.meaning: (weightlifting) The first part of the event clean and jerk in which the weight is brought from the ground to the shoulders.

verbs.description: clean (third-person singular simple present cleans, present participle cleaning, simple past and past participle cleaned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove dirt from a place or object.
examples: Can you clean the windows today?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To tidy up, make a place neat.
examples: Clean your room right now!

entries.meaning: (transitive, climbing) To remove equipment from a climbing route after it was previously lead climbed.
(intransitive) To make things clean in general.
examples: She just likes to clean. That’s why I married her.

entries.meaning: (transitive, computing) To remove unnecessary files, etc. from (a directory, etc.).
(intransitive, curling) To brush the ice lightly in front of a moving rock to remove any debris and ensure a correct line; less vigorous than a sweep.
(manga fandom slang) To purge a raw of any blemishes caused by the scanning process such as brown tinting and poor color contrast.
(video games) Synonym of clean up
To remove guts and/or scales of a butchered animal.
